Description: The upper part of a hollow terracotta devotee or priestess, perhaps of Isis, broken from a probably seated figure; her left arm (and perhaps her lost right arm) is bent at the elbow as though resting beside her thighs. She wears a chiton tied below the breasts, and has jewellery consisting of a plain necklet and a body-chain: she may be a bride. She has Isis-locks surmounted by a level wreath or a flat hat. Back plain; circular vent. Two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt, with some mica. Traces of a creamy-white dressing on the front.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Excavation no. A.B.2.3. Donated: Egypt Exploration Society. From Sir Robert Mond's 1927 excavations at Armant: no excavation details traced. Probably Roman, first or second century AD.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3163)
